para.text: Title
Your title should tell the reader exactly what the report is about.
Web Page Design
Contents list

If your report has a number of sections, it is important to include a table of contents so that the readers can find the information they want. Use the same section headings or numbers as you do in the main part of the report.
(Contents list optional for shorter reports, not included in this model.)
Summary
Include a summary of the purpose and objectives of the report, the kind of research you did, the main findings and conclusions, and your recommendations, if any.
TIP This is often called an executive summary. It follows the structure of the main report.
(Summary optional for shorter reports, not included in this model.)
Introduction
Give the background to why you are writing the report and explains what the report covers and what research you did.
Compare 2 web designs—see which people prefer.
What attracts people and makes them buy products?
The purpose of this report is
to compare two different web designs. The reason for this is to decide what kind of web page is most likely to attract new customers and to encourage existing customers to buy more products from us.
Main body of report
Give precise information about your research and what you have found.
TIP You can include tables and diagrams here, or these can be in an appendix.
Asked 2 developers for different page designs—one simple (A), one more sophisticated (B)
Research: 2 groups of 20 people (range of ages, professions, computer knowledge)
Made 2 groups: one used A, one B, once a day for a month to do tasks: buying, getting info, returning goods, tracking
Also asked about devices and connection speeds.
We asked

two developers to produce alternative web pages for our company. We asked Developer A to produce a simple, easy-to-use design and we asked Developer B to produce a more sophisticated design with lots of eye-catching graphics.
We conducted our research by
asking a group of twenty existing customers and twenty non-customers to use the web page over a month.
The group was made up of

people with a range of ages, professions, incomes and computer expertise. We divided the group in two and asked one sub-group to use Design A and the other to use Design B. We asked each sub-group to log on once a day and to use the web page to perform certain tasks, including: buying products, getting information, returning damaged products and tracking deliveries. We also asked the sub-groups to assess how attractive they found their designs and whether they would be encouraged to return to the web page.
In addition
we researched
the devices people used and the connection speeds available. We asked each group to note how long it took to download the web pages and to make an order.
Conclusions/Findings
Give the facts you have discovered and your opinions on them.
People liked easy-to-use page (A) for buying.
Don't want entertainment—Design B may be  slow to load, etc.
We found that, on the whole,
people preferred to be able to purchase products quickly and easily.
In conclusion,
users do not visit a site such as ours for entertainment. While they initially enjoyed some of the aspects of Design B, these could take a long time to load and users eventually became bored.
Recommendations
Base these on your conclusions.
TIP You can also predict what will happen if they are followed.
Adopt Design A (simple) with some features of B.
We recommend that
we adopt Design A with two or three of the more practical features from Design B.
Appendices
Give more detailed information here, with cross references to the appendices in the body of the report.
(Appendices optional for shorter reports, not included in this model.)
Bibliography
Give a list of any other publications you refer to in your report.
(Bibliography optional for shorter reports, not included in this model.)

steps.label: What is a report for?
desc: A report describes a study, an investigation or a project. Its purpose is to provide recommendations or updates, and sometimes to persuade the readers to accept an idea. It is written by a single person or a group who has investigated the issue. It is read by people who require the information.

steps.label: How is the report structured?
desc: Below is a framework for creating long reports.
The model you will see is an executive summary of a longer report so it does not include all of these sections.

steps.label: How was the report planned?
desc: In order to plan the report, the writer decides what to cover in each paragraph and takes notes.

steps.label: Show me useful language
desc: The writer uses key words or phrases to:

checkList.text: Do your research and gather all your information, including facts and figures.
Organize your notes into the framework.
Ask yourself questions about your readers.
checkList.tellMeMore:
You need to make the objective of the report clear so that people who are reading it know why they are reading. Thinking about the readers and what they need to know will help improve your report.

  • Is the purpose of the report clear throughout?
  • Can the readers find the information they need?
  • Will diagrams or tables make the information clearer?
  • Should I just present the facts or include recommendations as well?

checkList.text: Use language that is clear, accurate and formal.
Use language to state your objectives.
checkList.tellMeMore:
The purpose/aim/objective of this report is to...
This report aims to...
This report presents/gives information on...

checkList.text: Use language to outline your research and present your findings.
checkList.tellMeMore:
Outlining research
We asked (e.g. two developers) to...
We conducted our research by... (e.g. asking a group of...)
We examined/looked at/researched... (e.g. the problem/the cost/several companies)
We surveyed... (e.g. a total of 250 employees))
We compared A and B.
The group was made up of...
Presenting findings
We found that, on the whole,...
According to the majority of respondents...
Overall people preferred...
50% of those surveyed said (that)...

checkList.text: Use language to give conclusions and recommendations.
checkList.tellMeMore:
Giving Conclusions
In conclusion...
The research shows/demonstrates that...
The research shows/demonstrates + noun (e.g. the effect of...)
From the research/From the evidence we conclude that...
Giving recommendations
We recommend that...
It is recommended that...
The best solution is/would be to... (e.g. adopt design A)
The best solution is /would be + noun (e.g. a reduction in office hours)
If we do A, we will see B.
This will have an impact on + noun (e.g. costs /productivity/the business)

checkList.text: Make your report as long as necessary but as short as possible.
The main body of your report should be mainly factual and not based on opinion.
In internal reports, use we and I for describing research.
Do I have all the sections I need?
Does the title clearly show what the report is about?
Does the contents list have the same headings and numbers as the report?
Is the summary an accurate statement of the report?
Does the introduction state the purpose of the report?
Does the introduction say what the report will (and won't) cover?
Does the introduction explain the research?
Does the body of the report use headings and numbers?
Would tables or diagrams make the information clearer?
Does the conclusion clearly give my opinion about the findings?
Are my recommendations really based on my conclusion?
Have I checked vocabulary, grammar and spelling?
